												After being gifted this game, I really really want to recommend it, but I just can't. Here's why:Pros (+) :1. Pleasant and fitting music though it feels... Not so original.2. Strong monsters (for those of you who like strong enemies in games) that scale with your level, including their loot.3. Six different classes to choose from.4. The character art is pretty, but everything else is what you would expect of a game of that genre, nothing special or unique here.5. It's possible to upgrade your weapon as well as craft your own potions.6. It's a fairly cheap game.Cons (-) :1. Classes are way too similar to each other. In fact, it doesn't matter which one you pick as they hardly differ from each other at all as there are no special abilities or talents. All of the classes can use the two OP weapons I will mention further down in this review.2. Unfixed bugs are present in the game. Several of them. You can literally walk on the walls inside the church, an innkeeper won't allow you to enter the room you paid for and you can't walk behind a really tall building.3. Hardly any balancing in melee fights: Enemies have more hp and hit harder as you level, while you hardly become any stronger. In fact, it wasn't unusual for enemies to be able to kill me with 2-3 hits once I leveled up just a few times. And that was indeed as a melee class with a higher defense stat than mages and archers. Also, there are two swords that can be used by ALL classes, and those swords can kill just about every monster without them ever being able to hit you as you hit them diagonally, while they can only harm you when you are in their path.4. Spells are useless: only 2 spells and they don't really do any major damage. Also, enemies apparently have a 2 second or so invulnerability after being hit, which isn't much of an issue when using melee weapons (as a melee weapon takes about equally long to charge the attack), but it's a major issue when using spells as you have to time the spell right so you don't waste mana nor get hit while waiting for their invulnerability to wear off. Unnecesarily hard and really bothersome.5. Very few quests for a game of that genre: I could only find 4 in the game and I literally looked everywhere and talked to every single npc in the game. Oh and they don't really give any directions so you more or less have to guess where to go for x quest.6. Lacks content: Like I wrote above, enemies become stronger the higher level you are, and so it would be nice if you could buy or acquire better armor, but there isn't anything meant for mid-game fights and above. Also, why is there a random guy living in the middle of nowhere when he does nothing important? Why does everyone talk about the king and all when he actually proves to be completely irrelevant to the story and is, in fact, impossible to interact with? 7. Incomplete (or feels so) things: why are there guard towers with instructions on how to use smoke signals if you don't ever get to use it yourself or see it happen? Why are there so many locked doors?8. Doesn't really have a lot of different weapons to offer: Again, no need to acquire any other weapon than one of the two swords mentioned above.9. The crafting / upgrading system is more or less useless. Once you acquire either one of the swords (again with the swords…), you can literally just kill monsters without them ever being able to hit you, and only standard weapons sold by npcs can be upgraded, and the upgraded weapons are FAR inferior to those two swords. As for making your own potions, well, using OP swords will give you so much money that you will easily be able to buy more potions than you could ever need. Oh and if you really want to make your own potions, farming the ressources is a major pain and nearly impossible to do, as nothing says where to acquire them (apart from those blue butterflies). Just farm gold kay?.10. No "fast travel" or "teleport to x city/town": It's really annoying to travel through several zones 10 times while trying to avoid monsters (in EVERY zone) that can almost kill you with one hit.11. It's a fairly short game (fortunately?). I beat it first time as a ninja (the slow and long play-through to explore everything the game has to offer, and ninja is a melee class) in four hours, second time was to test the mage class and I completed it in aprox. 2, and the third was a speed run as an archer, which I completed in about an hour. I tried to beat the game using only magic and arrows, but I eventually gave up on both and just went the OP swords "route", which made the game A LOT easier.Final Verdict:Is it worth buying? Not really. I would probably recommend it if it had fewer bugs and more content, but right now it just feels empty content-wise after 30 or so minutes.

												Secret of Magia is an Action RPG developed with RPG Maker.I was given a key by the developer and I am sorry to say I do not recommend this game and here is why.Let's start with the good things first :The game offers not only between the choice of a female or male character, but features a class system that determines what can you equip. The HUD is nicely done and the quest system is rather original for a game like this.The combat system is pretty good and the enemies are implemented in a smart way, the skeletons in the mines were one of them, as they genuinely surprised me and made me paranoid.Another nice thing is that you can gather flowers and butterflies for the crafting system, sadly after an hour and a half I have not tried this system yet, but I gathered quite a lot of stuff.Now for the bad parts :I'm not sure if the developer has tested this game, but it's full of bugs, you can go inside walls, letters become plants when you read them, some blocks that should be solid are not, some that shouldn't be are, glitches here and there, couches have teleport blocks inside them, I was joking with a friend that in the first chuch you come across you can ascend to godhood by straight walking on the wall, most of the walls there are passable, even npcs climb them.The combat while original for the first half hour, is kind of unbalanced, at least as a melee class, I was getting oneshotted the first levels which was pretty frustrating (slimes), I had to align myself diagonally so the monsters wouldn't have a chance to attack me but I could. I farmed a little, when I leveled up though, the monsters leveled with me and became a lot more tanky, giving more gold too. Now, the first real boss was not a big problem because by the time I had so many money I invested in health potions, he could never kill me, doesn't matter how much damage he did to me. After that you drop a legendary weapon which is a bow, a weapon my assassin shouldn't be using but he was using anyway (not sure if legendary weapons do not have class requirements). Some of the resources are inherent to RPG Maker and not original by the developer, you can judge if that affects quality or not.I do not feel compelled to complete or continue the game as I did not have much fun with it, but thank you anyway for this chance (since I received the key by a developer or someone in contact with him).All in all it's a low quality rpg maker title with some smart ideas here and there, but with a weak story, characters and quite full of bugs at the moment of writing, so personally I would not recommend you this game.

												A technically flawed but mostly charming and low priced action adventure/RPG title, Secret Of Magia harkens back to older action adventure RPG titles and the inspirations and love for the Zelda titles is clear, and things like the friendly dialogue, brief random encounters, art style and music all fit nicely. There's also a fair amount of content, areas and enemies for the cost, and overall, while it has problems and does nothing special, it's good value for money and a competent aaRPG.Full disclosure: I recieved a Steam key prior to this review.HighlightsThe variety of environments and pretty good intro level were enough to get me engaged, and the casual and unlimited nature of exploration from an early stage are worth mentioning. It's easy to skip ahead if you're impatient, but equally easy to spend an extra hour or two just exploring and grinding. There's also a variety of competent and occasionally funny dialogue from many different denizens in many different towns.The music is also very pleasant to listen to, and sets the tone really well without getting annoying at all.Overall, if the developer releases a patch or two and clears up some issues, this title will be worth picking up for what is essentially the price of a coffee.Mistakes and AnnoyancesI feel like a patch or two would fix up most of my complaints, but for the sake of completion and honesty here they are.There are tons of small technical bugs. I routinely found myself clipping through walls and into inaccessible areas, I was unable to equip or de-equip items after certain encounters, and had no way to continue but to slowly suicide, menu systems sometimes became disabled for unidentifiable reasons and plenty more small annoying technical mistakes that should've been play-tested and fixed.The support for using a mouse is great, and makes playing a lot faster and smoother, but the out of the box key bindings are frankly awful, and the in-game configuration panel isn't listed in the controls, nor accessible by anything other than messing around (it's F1 in all RPG Maker titles), and even that isn't properly labelled or actionable, and F12 causes crashes due to a bugged RPG Maker script. Again, these are little things that can be fixed fairly simply, but that's all the more reason to highlight them.There are design mistakes too, namely the save system relying on positional altar markers. This means that, like some of the older Zelda systems, you can only save before entering an area or after travelling to a specific place. For a game that encourages player grinding and a slow death screen, this makes little sense. An auto-save or simply just a save button would've been a far better choice.The main issue for me, however, was the combat. There is arguably a small level of skill required in coordinating where to position the player in regards to each enemy and the environment but, at least as the soldier class, it's mostly just about finding the next diagonal tile and slashing ad infinitum and became repetitive and bland after a short time and even boss fights are mostly about predicting the next move and getting in position.RecommendationsPriced at just £1.99/2.99€/$2.99 at the time of review, this is actually priced fairly, and will probably be worth picking up on sale for someone looking for a casual aaRPG with a nod towards older Nintendo titles, just not until some of the technical problems are corrected.

												Autumn 2015. Steam sale. Bundle of RPG Maker games for $2. 4 games, $0.50 each. I said sure, why not, how bad could it be? What is the Secret of Magia?It's a lie. It's a farce. It's a buggy, broken, terribly developed, messy piece of junk that should not be on Steam. Yet somehow it is. And if just playing the game wasn't enough, digging into these Steam reviews is even more eye-opening than one would think.When the dev himself is complaining about the publisher messing up his game, screwing it up, and even trying to hide that IT is the publisher (Epic Quest Games), you know something is foul.But if finding all those solid negative reviews and reading them isn't enough, have some more with this one.Action RPG? Yes, but only barely. Inspired by great games? Possibly, but this is so barebones and by the book that it hardly echoes of any of them mentioned on the Store page. Huge world? Nonsense. It's small enough to be easily beaten in less than 3 hours, AND you even have the in-game maps found to prove it. Tyranny of an evil, supernatural dictator? More like an ambiguous bird being who wakes you up and threatens your life if you don't gather plot items (as seen in one of the screenshots).I mean honestly the entire "About This Game" bit can be properly summarized down to "Secret of Magia is an action RPG. Your story begins in a town. As you venture out, you'll earn levels and find obvious dungeons that have broken weapons. You start weak, you'll get strong, and you will never need to go back to your starting village. Explore a tiny world, grind aimlessly on cheap monsters, and go beat up the final boss."4 side-quests of a moderately ambiguous nature. A really tiny overworld. Practically no plot whatsoever beyond "go find the four things". Flatter, more two dimensional characters than paper. Enemies that level with you, a battle system that is easily broken, weapon crafting and item drops that serve no real solid purpose. And a final boss who upon defeat compliments you then kicks you back to the title screen. That same final boss is the one who kick starts the plot to begin with, and that's basically all the plot you get.Secret of Magia is ONLY worth the cards it drops, and even then how much can you make? This is better off lost and forgotten about, tossed into the proverbial rubbish as it is now. Do not repeat my mistake.Because honestly, even fifty cents worth of candy gives more enjoyment than Secret of Magia.

												Secret of Magia looked like it was going to be a retro RPG, taking me back to the days of the Nintendo and Super Nintendo.  Playing Dragon Warrior, Faria, Times of Lore, or even Ultima to some extent. Starting out, you are in a room with Two characters, while you control a black sphere.  I was given the option choosing which Hero I wanted to play as by going through One of Two doors on either side of each Hero. I selected a character and was taken to a black screen where dialogue appeared. It seemed there was some sort of overarching villain who wanted "the elements" and threatened to reap your soul if you didn't get them for him. You then wake up in the bed of an inn, where you find a memo telling you to go to the bottom of a well to prove your worth. There was no tutorial playthrough where you learn how to open the menu, switch between various screens, equip items or gear, or to even orient you to your basic surroundings. I thought this was a little clumsy, because a lot of the good RPG games have these basic features. So it took a few moments to explore the keyboard to figure out how to open the menus and switching between things. Instead of my usual exploring I decided to follow the storyline and proceeded to a well where I descended and encountered rats. The game told me to equip a sword, but didn't explain how to do that: Luckily, I fooled around with the keyboard so I knew where to go and what to do. Rat-Kabob coming up. Then, I was told to equip a lantern, but for the life of me I couldn't find it in the inventory. Finally after 3 minutes of frustration I was able to locate a lantern, by going to my armor, selecting equip and there it was, hidden. Frustrated, I equipped it and proceeded through the cave slashing at rats.I think this game has some things going for it. Visually it is retro, but done in a good way. The story seems interesting, very Final Fantasyish; However, Ithink the dialogue is a little weak and the menu system is clunky. Perhaps playing further will alleviate my frustrations and I will be pleasantly surprised. For now though, based on my initial interaction with the game I think it is mediocre. Some things are done well, others not so well. It is playable and it is still an interesting RPG. I give it a thumbs up, but would urge caution for those who are easily frustrated or have unrealistic expectations.

												It's a quickly-played, quickly-made RPG Maker action RPG game.  RPG Maker notoriously handles anything but the turn-based actions it was made to handle quite poorly, so the game can be clunky at times, but it's not QUITE as bad as most action RPGs on RPG maker is.  Still, I would suggest looking to something made in another engine for any substansive action RPG fix, because this game is anemic in content, and has no interesting gimmicks to make it stand out compared to the hundred other Zelda-wannabes on Steam.Pros:* Dirt cheap, so you won't regret it long even if you don't like it.* It's fairly fast-paced, and you level up quickly with relatively little grinding. * It's possible to just run past most of the enemies.* Six possible classes.* If you aren't going for cards, you can beat the game fast enough to return it for a refund!Cons: * The enemies are rubber-banded to your level, while your stat-boosting equipment is based upon how far in the plot you have progressed, meaning you lose power relative to your enemies as you gain levels.* The enemies meander around until it's time for their attack, at which point they fly at you at mach 12, clip through your own attacks, and keep chasing you even if you do hit them in the middle of their attack.  * You have a shield button, but except for the archer, you have to be a melee class to get it, and there's no wind-up animation to warn you to raise your shield before they start running at you, so you need to use psychic precognition to tell when to use your shield when you're standing only 1-2 tiles away.* The enemies deal about 1/5 your total health per hit.* The enemies have about second-long invulnerability after being hit, and can attack immediately after that.* The enemies can stun-lock you in place with spammed ranged attacks * The classes are not described in-game at all, and have unintuitive effects.* The classes are not balanced at all.* The archer class relies upon arrows, can only carry 99 at a time, I shot 50 getting from the first town to the second, and the second town doesn't have arrow vendors.  * The spells deal 1/6th the damage a physical attack does no matter what your magic stat is, so mages are useless.* All other classes are melee classes, and any melee class besides Paladin is just plain weaker than the Paladin.  * Bugs galore! Walk through walls! Don't walk through objects that look the same as ones you can walk through! Enter one house, leave out a different one!* The writing is as utterly barebones as possible.  "Go kill this thing for me." "Thank you for killing it.  Here's the ___ I promised." * The plot consists of your character having a dream where a bird tells you to go kill four bosses and bring it their souls or it'll eat your soul.  You find these bosses literally just sitting out in a field, and after you're done killing all four, you get a final boss, then, BAM, credits, game over.  * You will finish in about an hour if you don't grind, and the game punishes you for grinding, anyway.

The Secret of Magia dares you to play it, comparing it to RPG greats such as the Legend of Zelda and Secret of Mana.Do you have what it takes to delve into this story's mysteries?Are YOU ready for ADVENTURE?!? Are you looking for fun?Then look somewhere else.Concept & Story:Secret of Magia is standard Japanese Role-Playing-Game fare. There is nothing new brought to the table. Some may be fine with this approach, as was I. However, there is hardly any story at all. The game opens with a monstrous bird that threatens to kill you if you do not return with four crystals... at least it appears to threaten you. Significant grammatical errors are made immediately. While these can be sludged though and understood because of context, they persist throughout the game, sometimes making sentences nonsensical. This problem never alleviates. There are portions of text that lead completely off the screen, leaving the player to guess what was being said. After leaving the introduction, our hero is set on a set of sidequests. That's it: five sidequests that aren't really tied in any way to the plot. The plot, of course, does not exist. It is only revisited at the end of the game and very, very briefly at that. While it is typically considered in bad taste to spoil the ending of a game or film, I cannot do so, though I am sorely tempted to. You see, the ending... it doesn't exist. As the boss lays dying, you are returned to the title screen. No credits, no "Thank you for playing", not even "Game Over"; there is absolutely nothing following this. This isn't just unexpected in story-based games, it's just downright rude.Concept & Story - 2/10Gameplay:This sort of title has many expected mechanics in gameplay style. It is clear what the developer was aiming for, it just misses the mark in each and every way. Full controller support is claimed, but this is false. Movement, with a control pad, is only permitted with the analog stick, not the directional pad. This sort of game would have played much better with the latter. Giving players the option of either or best would work for everyone. Instead, the developer chose otherwise. The buttons used for play are odd in placement and incredibly awkward throughout the game. It is not unusual for them to be nonresponsive. Sometimes, there is a significant delay between pressing buttons and having a chosen action take place. This is inexcusable.Navigating menus is slow, tedious, and excessive. Early in the game, the player is asked to equip items that aren't even present. They come into existence only when suggested by the interface. Other portions of inventory are completely unused, specifcally charms and accessories. It is as if something were planned and then completely forgotten. Evidently, the forgetfullness persisted through alpha and beta testing, if there was any at all.The game utilizes class systems, levels, and crafting. This would seem a good idea. Class choice makes little difference as they play nearly the same. When leveling, your character becomes stronger. Unfortunately, the enemies gain in strength, health, and resistances to your attacks... and very disproportionally so. In other words, "leveling up" not only does not help you, it is an extremely bad idea. Under no conditions should the player consider grinding for experience; they may find the game unfinishable. Crafting is introduced to upgrade weapons and to create potions. In fact, one entire town in the game is dedicated to the industry of alchemy and potions. This system is never flushed out and developed. It suggests itself to have great promise and then proceeds to be completely ignored. There is no reason to bother with crafting weapons of any sort.There are more concerns about things that would never be discussed if it were not for the fact that these normal mechanics are broken. Sleeping in village inns poses the slight risk of waking up in another town. It would appear that the screens that the interiors of the Inns are not reliably linked to the screens of the towns. As such, about one out of three nights spent will leave you across the world. When fighting certain enemies, the player can be stunned. This, in it of itself, is normally not an issue, but menu access is also locked. Any attempts to access the Game Menu or otherwise Pause are also "stunned". The entire game locks until the Effect wears off. There is no reason for this. Frequently, the player will become stunned even if not hit with a stunning attack. There is no way to predict when this will happen. Furthermore, progress through the four key dungeons is dependend on acquiring unique keys held be mini-bosses. Sometimes they drop them upon death... sometimes they don't. If not, pray you did not save, as the required Key is now and forever inaccessible. The only solution is to reset or load from a previous save file and try again.For what should be simple and casual play and control, The Secret of Magia fails even at this minimal task.Gameplay - 3/10Sound & Music:The sounds are fine and what would be expected for this sort of game. While voice-acting is a nice feature, it is not neccessary. Music is acceptable. It isn't awful, but it isn't memorable either. It is the sort of thing one would expect if a developer snatched up a few royalty-free music tracks and tossed in the ones that sounded best. Actually, this is exactly what developer, Lunatiod, did. The exact same music can be heard in other games as well. Even if they chose to use synthesised MIDI tracks that someone composed with this title in mind, it could have added more substance. Sound & Music - 5/10Graphics:JRPGs have a typical look to them and this title attempts to keep up with the look and style of these. It is light and whimsical, with a touch of cartoony adventure. This being said, it is expected that things are consistent. Windows appear out of the edges of the walls of a church. Players walk right over gates. The player can even walk into and through some walls. Frequently when moving, the player will appear to be using their "Hookshot" item, when no such device is in use. These realatively easy fixes persist.Most striking is the fact that the game does not appear as shown in the presented screenshots and advertisment video. It is extremely clear that the developer or publisher used photo and/or video editing software to make the game appear to have a very different asthetic than is actually present. In short, this is false advertising. This sort of practice is loathesome and completely disqualifies this aspect of the game.Graphics - 0/10Enjoyability and Replay Value:Secret of Magia showed a certain amount of promise. Each promise suggested was carelessly broken. Even if one sets their expectations low, this particular title fails to meet even that. This was an attempt to be a game without any intention to put in effort. It is hours of constant frustration dealing with glitches and broken game mechanics, a lack of story. and a complete absense of any fun. They entire game plays out as if "fun" is going to be right around the corner; it never comes.Since all characters are virtually the same, despite what their names suggest, there isn't a reason to try these variations out. There is not much in the way of secrets, so outside of a hidden dagger (with coordinates that mean nothing), there is nothing to go back for. It isn't even the sort of game that one can enjoy the story once more, because there is practically no story and what little is presented is certainly not enjoyable. It isn't fun or remotely interesting. It offers absolutely nothing.Enjoyability and Replay Value - 2/10Final Thoughts:It is obvious that the publisher and developer were interested in creating something that could be called a game, on paper. At 49 cents for this and three other titles, I feel ripped off. A waste of two hours. Avoid.Overall - 2/10

Few enemies telegraph their attacks - not only do enemies hit hard, but there are only a few enemies for which you can actually tell that they are about to attack and dodge. Stun + no temporary immunity = 1-hit KO - when you get hit, you are stunned for a little while. The moment you can move again, you are vulnerable. This means that enemies that attack multiple times in a row can (and usually will) hit you multiple times. This leads to you being stuck, watching your character get hit over and over until they die without you being able to do anything about it (other than burning through healing items until the enemy stops attacking).The combat system really could be fun, but there's no room for skill. 												This game feels like it's trying to do the Y Chronicals or Link to the Past thing, where combat takes place in real time, rather than in the typical random enounter way. The problem with this is that the RPG Maker engine wasn't meant for this type of combat. Developers, I congratulate you for making the game do it... but it's a shame you didn't do it well.I learned that this game uses a system where enemiew level up with the player. A novel concept, but it utterly fails in practice. Developers, I'm sorry. But you picked the wrong genre to include such a feature, because doing this punishes the player for grinding. When you have a game that rewards players for killing enemies with exp, money, and crafting items, chances are we're going to be encouraged to fight as many things as we can see. And the combat system you developed makes it really easy to kill a ton of things early on. But as you level up, enemies will start to take more and more hits to kill. And then you'll reach level 5 during the first notable quest, only to get gored by a bee on the way back.Killing 20 slimes doesn't turn the rest of them into liquid iron. Not in a logical world, anyways.Writing is extremely poor early on. Who am I? Why do I down a rat infested well to train? What "training" do I get done by beating up on an archery target with a knife? How did guy from the guild see me training on the cliff side? I never say any other spot in town where someone could get that kind of view. The moment I'm done with that training, he comes to me and says he'll give me a weapons license and a guild membership. Is it really that easy to join this guild? I wouldn't mind if the writing wasn't handled so clumsily. If you have a guild with criteria to join, it's typically best to have the player go to the guild, and be given some sort of minor adventuring quest to join it. Not saying you have to fit the generic mold; but either make joining the adventurers guild some sort of major feat for the character, or have them already in it. Otherwise, joining feels meaningless. Another protip would be to think of catchier names for towns and people. I know that seems like nitpicking. But it helps your world to make it memorable.And here's a protip for using the RPG VX ACE maker. I noticed this when I stepped on a patch of tall grass, and it looked like I was floating on top of it. If you go into your tilesets, where most tiles have like an X or O on it, there should be an option that looks like 2 wavy lines. I don't have it pulled up right now, so I can't give the actual name for it. But it'll make it to where characters get their lower half shaded when walking over a section. This creates the illusion that your character has the grass coming up to his waist. Just apply it to the tall grass sections and you're good.Overall, it's a game I fell if I do complete, it'll be by force. Sorry guys. This just wasn't your game.

I got a copy in a pack of 4 RPGs i wanted to try for ~60p, thankfully.Obvious problems:You get direction for what to do for the first 5 minutes ('Go to the well'), after that, you're free to wander the entire map (and good luck finding a map so you can squint and get an idea of where the hell you are or what you're supposed to be doing.) Quests have no markers - if it says 'go and kill blah', and you don't know where blah is, then so begins a wild goose chase.After you save the miner...you can go back to the mine with the dungeon key and have a go at the fire boss...but not if you can't equip a shield.It might just be because i picked the mage class, but i couldn't equip a shield despite buying everything possible (currency is nowhere near balanced, items cost ~30 gold and you can earn 1000s in minutes). No shield? No hope in hell of beating the elemental bosses. Was i supposed to buy 99 health potions and spam those instead??? (for shame)While normal attack damage is ok and different weapons do different AoE areas (the combat system is quite interesting actually), magic is realllllly weak :/ like not even worth having. It's good for long distance but not when it does 10 damage against an enemy with 1000s of HP - who doesn't always stay STILL - who has time for that?Enemies are all overpowered - i got to ~lvl 16 and even the wasps were taking off ~1/5 of my health per attack. Only the rats in the well at the very start of the game seem like they're at the right level for your character, and if you go back down there, they can divebomb you to hell and back in seconds. The screen is littered with annoyance after annoyance and they don't scale with you nor drop anything significant. You're thrown in at the deep-end and get nothing for not drowning.You can only save at the green flames and not the barely-existent menu, which i thought was a bit annoying because you have to backtrack to the last village and hope you can remember where it is in that village/town - some sign posts really wouldn't go amiss.NPCs are pretty lifeless - if you ever even find one, chances are they'll just talk about their house (i found books in ONE house, all the other houses are window dressing :/) Ok, Sir/Madam, your house is nice and all....(not if there's nothing to loot lol) but how about some lore or something? Why go on???I don't hate the game, but it really needs a lot of work. Tone down the difficulty (there doesn't have to be an enemy everywhere), scale enemies to class and level - battles are supposed to be FUN. Put in more 'where to go if you're stuck' (signposts!) . Know your characters - do we get a party at some point?? Why are we being forced by some flying bird to collect all the elements? Because it will 'reap our soul' otherwise? Well that's very nice of it???? haha

												Initial Review (bear in mind I only played for an hour before deciding I wouldn't like it):1. Introduction was quick enough.  However, my interest wasn't piqued much.  A strange bird tells you to get all four elements or he'd reap your soul.  You get to choose your gender and class (assassin, archer or mage).  That's it.  2. You wake up in a city and you're being told what to do next exactly.  The game pushes you in the direction you have to go.  Not much thought process involved at all.3. The combat system is Zelda-like; Secret of Magia is an action RPG where you press Z to swing your weapon, S to block with a shield, A to cast a spell.  Easy enough at first, but you can be one-shot by some enemies as melee rather easily if you don't act quickly enough.  The shield that I bought from the weaponmaker after receiving the license in town didn't seem to be working either (and I made sure to equip it, too).  And the monsters really do move too fast for you to avoid them sometimes. 4. There are background bugs everywhere.  Cliffs and walls are passable when they shouldn't be, etc.5. No proofreading has been done for this game, apparently.  Dialogue is full of typos and misspellings - you'll be talking to plenty of 'Gaurds,' for example - and even with that fixed, it's not particularly memorable.  Many of the NPC's lines are nothing special.  "I love my nice house!"  One guard said that they couldn't drink in the watchtower and giggled as he said it - which seemed weirdly out of place.6. Quests are discovered by talking to NPCs with an exclamation point or by examining books or so on - they seem to be straightforward but there was one quest that pointed out a location of a dagger while giving you coordinates.  I'm not sure how that would have been accomplished without an add-on telling you X and Y coordinates of the map you were on.  Granted, I didn't play long enough to try to figure it out.7. Did I mention you could be one-shot rather easily?  Now there aren't enough save points to really help you avoid a lot of experience and gold loss if that happens.  I decided not to risk entering the mines and try to find a save point because of it in the next town up.  This isn't really a criticism.  I like the challenge, but it can probably be discouraging to some.8. The Dash function is default (and essential in avoiding monsters); however the game's frame rate doesn't seem to be very smooth when you're dashing.  I've seen this done better in other RPGMaker games like Labyronia.  It's a bit distracting in this game.9. There are two different ways you can use items: through equipping them, and by using the Q-W quick item equipper.  I think the item equipper could have probably been removed to simplify up the UI a bit in that respect.10. There was a map inside the training hall in the first city that showed you the first few areas as if they were zoomed out.  I play RPGs to explore areas myself, so that map kind of took away most of the mystery of the first few areas for me.All in all, unfortunately I wouldn't recommend this game.  EDIT: I bought it on sale ($1) and still feel ripped off - and now I find out from reading other reviews, if I had kept playing, I would have completed it in 2.5 to 3 hours anyway... I feel like there are a lot of better games for your money's worth.  Labyronia for one, which I mentioned.

What it fails to do is execute these well and the game just turns into a giant mess. All you have to do is stand to the side of where they can hit, and so long as they don't have some sort of area of effect skill they just can't hit you. One NPC remarked that you needed a shield to beat a particular boss. This boss was actually one of the only ones I couldn't abuse this hitbox effect on and I still never even used the shield (playing as a Paladin).Secret of Magia holds some good promises but completely fails to deliver on them. Many glitches are being left unchecked, such as being locked out of dungeons forcing you to restart the entire game and the Scythe just not being upgradeable. There are much better games in this style out there, so my suggested is to just play those instead and pass on Secret of Magia. Unless, of course, you don't mind smashing your head into awful English and poor hitboxes.

Full DisclosureI was given this a copy game by the developer(s) (or someone in contact with them) to review.ReviewSecret of Magia is a bit of an interesting title for me, at first I was rather enjoying it. It had an OK story, some character progression and even some nice things like a HookShot! Unfortunately it went downhill from there (and before that even). I personally played this game with an Xbox 360 controller, as that's what I generally enjoy playing this style of game with. Sadly there appears to be no documentation of the controls for it. So here's roughly what they seem to be for me:A - Run/Walk + HookshotB - Menu (Really odd binding IMO)X - Attack/InteractY - MagicLB - ShieldSelect - Quick Menu (also used for cycling between quick menus)Start - Also used for cycling quick menus, but cannot be used to access it in the first place)RB/LT/RT - Appear to be unused.Now while the game was fun for the first hour or so, unforunately it simply became a grindfest of bugs and dull combat. It is worth noting that I played as a Paladin class, so other classes *may* be more interesting, but for me it simply consisted of standing diagonally from an enemy and spamming the attack button (the cooldown on combos seems very short IMO). This tactic ends up changing slightly for enemies that have a ranged attack as I will simply attack them head on because they have no melee secondary attack, leaving them essentially paralyzed while I attack them. Magic attacks are OK, but they have no cooldown meaning they can easily be spammed. (I only seemed to have access to a fire spell and ice spell as a Paladin, with the ice being a sort of ball shot straight ahead, and the fire being multiple revolving fireballs). Now you might seem to think that combat isn't so bad from this, but enemies get tougher the higher level you are, the problem is that while their health gets ever higher my attack doesn't seem to level at the same rate (or at all), with most monsters now taking up to 70 (yes seventy) hits to defeat at level 16 with the best weapons I currently have.I also have ended up with virtually endless money as well from every monster I come across up to the first boss, meaning I can basically never die by drinking as many life potions as needed due to them having no cooldown.It is also worth noting that the game has no hint system or in-game map (short of the maps you can find on tables in some houses). I have played through as much of the game as I can, but I cannot find a key item, despite knowing roughly where it is, this is also despite having the key item that should come after it (as far as I know).SPOILERS:I cannot find the Wind Element, I assume it is in the catacombs but I do not know how to get in there as it appears to have a never ending staircase (as seen in Super Mario 64). I also already have the Fire, Ice and Earth Elements.Now I suppose we must move onto the bugs I discussed earlier. Some of these have already been mentioned in other reviews, but I will mention them again nonetheless.- The lighting engine appears to be broken entirely, I didn't realise this until looking at the screenshots now with their lovely lighting, yet my game appears to be running at max brightness with no shadows or dynamic lighting of any kind, the game looks almost completely different without it.- Many objects are solid for no apparent reason (such as foliage, there are some flowers that are seemingly identical, yet one is solid, the other isn't)- Many walls aren't solid (e.g. Multiple walls in the Church aren't solid meaning you (and NPCs) can walk on them.- There's a key that you can pick up In the Ancient Forest in an area with a Waterfall and Cave that I can pick up as many times as I want for no apparent reason, I now have 7 of said key in my inventory.- This is not necessarily a bug per se, but I noticed that after a couple of hours of playing my ears were beginning to hurt, the sound effects for melee attacks appears to be rather harsh, thankfully I was able to disable this via the RPGMaker menu (F1).Really I just don't think I can recommend this game, it has too many bugs, combat has become tedious (I avoid as many enemies as I can now), and it just wasn't a particularly fun experience (apart from the first 30min-1hr). Maybe once Secret of Magia gets updated a bit I'll revisit it and update my review, but for now I cannot recommend it.
